articles.headline: Empty Shelves Signal Revival in Game Consoles
articles.snippet: Those sales bolster the view that the console business is turning into a two-horse race, with Nintendo a distant third.
articles.abstract: Those sales bolster the view that the console business is turning into a two-horse race, with Nintendo a distant third.
articles.lead_paragraph: It might take a miracle from the North Pole for video game fans to get their wish this season.

articles.headline: Babes in a Digital Toyland: Even 3-Year-Olds Get Gadgets
articles.snippet: Parents with young children are buying them tablets and other devices, while the toy industry stalls, but retro toys, perhaps in a backlash, are resurgent.
articles.abstract: Parents with young children are buying them tablets and other devices, while the toy industry stalls, but retro toys, perhaps in a backlash, are resurgent.
articles.lead_paragraph: The children come day after day, lining up in the cold and snow on Main Street in Midland, Mich., to wait their turn to enter Santa’s house and whisper their Christmas longings to the jolly man in the red suit.
articles.byline: By Hilary Stout and Elizabeth A. Harris

articles.headline: U.N. Chief Urges Steps to Calm South Sudan’s Growing Conflict
articles.snippet: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon is seeking a near doubling of the peacekeeping force in the country, where civil war has become a rising threat.
articles.abstract: Secretary General Ban Ki-moon is seeking a near doubling of the peacekeeping force in the country, where civil war has become a rising threat.
articles.lead_paragraph: NAIROBI, Kenya — The new nation of South Sudan, created in an enormous international effort to end decades of conflict, moved closer to civil war on Monday, as the government vowed to storm cities under rebel control and the United Nations secretary general urged a major increase in peacekeepers to help protect tens of thousands of civilians.
articles.byline: By Nicholas Kulish, Michael R. Gordon and Somini Sengupta

articles.headline: ‘Safe Harbor’ in Bankruptcy Is Upended in Detroit Case
articles.snippet: Before it declared bankruptcy Detroit made a deal with two banks on money it owed them in line with safe harbor rules for derivatives traders, in what could end up as a better deal than what other creditors receive.
articles.abstract: Before it declared bankruptcy Detroit made a deal with two banks on money it owed them in line with safe harbor rules for derivatives traders, in what could end up as a better deal than what other creditors receive.
articles.lead_paragraph: As Detroit struggles to come up with money to improve services for its residents, two large banks are poised to receive hundreds of millions of dollars to cancel a deal that helped push the city into bankruptcy in the first place.

articles.headline: $40 Million in Aid Set for Bangladesh Garment Workers
articles.snippet: The fund for the Rana Plaza factory building collapse is considered a landmark in compensating families of garment industry victims, in terms of both the amount to be paid and the sophistication of the arrangements.
articles.abstract: The fund for the Rana Plaza factory building collapse is considered a landmark in compensating families of garment industry victims, in terms of both the amount to be paid and the sophistication of the arrangements.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eight months after the Rana Plaza factory building collapsed in Bangladesh, killing more than 1,100 workers and leaving hundreds of families bereft and financially adrift, several prominent retailers and labor groups have joined with the Bangladesh government to create an estimated $40 million compensation fund to aid the victims’ families.

articles.headline: Cohen Said to Have Warned Friend About Possible Federal Investigation
articles.snippet: Sources briefed on the insider trading investigation into Steven A. Cohen, the head of SAC Capital, say that a call in 2009 raised his suspicions.
articles.abstract: Sources briefed on the insider trading investigation into Steven A. Cohen, the head of SAC Capital, say that a call in 2009 raised his suspicions.
articles.lead_paragraph: By the summer of 2009, the billionaire investor Steven A. Cohen appeared to be growing suspicious that federal authorities were gathering evidence about insider trading in the hedge fund industry.

articles.headline: Upstart Groups Challenge Rove for G.O.P. Cash
articles.snippet: At least a dozen new groups are setting up to back individual Republican candidates for the Senate, threatening the strategic and financial dominance of Karl Rove and the nonprofit he co-founded, American Crossroads.
articles.abstract: At least a dozen new groups are setting up to back individual Republican candidates for the Senate, threatening the strategic and financial dominance of Karl Rove and the nonprofit he co-founded, American Crossroads.
articles.lead_paragraph: A quiet but intense struggle over money and influence is roiling the Republican Party just as the 2014 election season is getting underway.

articles.headline: A New Alliance Steps Up to Protect a New Generation of Models
articles.snippet: Model Alliance is working to prevent abuses like agencies cheating models out of pay and coercive contracts.
articles.abstract: Model Alliance is working to prevent abuses like agencies cheating models out of pay and coercive contracts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sara Ziff was a 14-year-old student at the Bronx High School of Science when a fashion photographer “discovered” her as she was returning to her family’s apartment in Greenwich Village.

articles.headline: Winning Veterans’ Trust, and Profiting From It
articles.snippet: Older veterans are being coaxed into paying for services or investments and signing contracts that lock them into long-term living arrangements.
articles.abstract: Older veterans are being coaxed into paying for services or investments and signing contracts that lock them into long-term living arrangements.
articles.lead_paragraph: With every slip and fall, every bruise and ache, the reality set in: Henry Schaffer, 86, could no longer live on his own. So his daughter, Kristi, began searching for a retirement home — and the money to pay for it.

articles.headline: Diverse Views on Reasons and Prospects for British Recovery
articles.snippet: Explaining what prompted Britain’s recovery amounts to an economic policy Rorschach test: are the austerity policies choking Europe’s growth or fostering it?
articles.abstract: Explaining what prompted Britain’s recovery amounts to an economic policy Rorschach test: are the austerity policies choking Europe’s growth or fostering it?
articles.lead_paragraph: LONDON — European economic recoveries are graded on a curve these days.

articles.headline: China’s Central Bank Eases Fears of Credit Crisis
articles.snippet: The People’s Bank of China on Tuesday provided around $5 billion in new liquidity to money markets that had been seized by soaring rates.
articles.abstract: The People’s Bank of China on Tuesday provided around $5 billion in new liquidity to money markets that had been seized by soaring rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — China’s central bank injected fresh money into the markets on Tuesday, easing the pressure on the financial system and quelling fears about a credit crisis.

articles.headline: Futuristic Mac Pro Has Power to Spare
articles.snippet: Apple’s new Mac Pro is aimed at the creative professionals who have always relied on Macs for video, graphics, music and photo manipulation.
articles.abstract: Apple’s new Mac Pro is aimed at the creative professionals who have always relied on Macs for video, graphics, music and photo manipulation.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the moment, I am living the life of a tech one-percenter.

articles.headline: Political Fight in South Sudan Targets Civilians
articles.snippet: The crisis in South Sudan has broadened into a conflict in which longstanding ethnic divisions are fueling the violence and civilians are not accidental victims of the fighting.
articles.abstract: The crisis in South Sudan has broadened into a conflict in which longstanding ethnic divisions are fueling the violence and civilians are not accidental victims of the fighting.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUBA, South Sudan — The security forces went house to house, rounding up civilians by the dozens and binding the wrists of some with wire, survivors said. Some were summarily shot in the street, they said, while others were hauled off to crowded cells. Bodies of the executed were tossed into shallow graves, one recalled. Another jail where civilians had been taken reeked of death, a witness said.
